description: From Middle English trotten, from Old French trotter, troter (‚Äúto go, trot‚Äù), from Medieval Latin *trott≈ç, *trot≈ç (‚Äúto go‚Äù), from Frankish *trott≈çn (‚Äúto go, run‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *trud≈çnƒÖ, *trudanƒÖ, *tradjanƒÖ (‚Äúto go, step, tread‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *dreh‚ÇÇ- (‚Äúto run, escape‚Äù). Cognate with Old High German trott≈çn (‚Äúto run‚Äù), Modern German trotten (‚Äúto trot, plod‚Äù), Gothic êçÑêçÇêåøêå≥êå∞êåΩ (trudan, ‚Äúto tread‚Äù), Old Norse tro√∞a (‚Äúto walk, tread‚Äù), Old English tredan (‚Äúto step, tread‚Äù). Doublet of tread.

entries.meaning: (archaic, derogatory) An ugly old woman, a hag. [From 1362.]
(chiefly of horses) A gait of a four-legged animal between walk and canter, a diagonal gait (in which diagonally opposite pairs of legs move together).
examples: Dogs have a variety of gaits. Most dogs have the walk, trot, pace, and gallop.

entries.meaning: A gait of a person or animal faster than a walk but slower than a run.

examples: We often take the car and have a trot down to the beach.
In this lesson we'll have a quick trot through Chapter 3 before moving on to Chapter 4.
[‚Ä¶] but Ethel romped with the little children ‚Äî the rosy little trots ‚Äî and took them on her knees, and told them a thousand stories.

entries.meaning: (Australia, obsolete) A succession of heads thrown in a game of two-up.
(Australia, New Zealand, with "good" or "bad") A run of luck or fortune.
examples: He‚Ä≤s had a good trot, but his luck will end soon.

entries.meaning: (dated, slang, among students) Synonym of horse (illegitimate study aid)

examples: He's got a bad case of the trots and has to keep running off to the toilet.

verbs.description: trot (third-person singular simple present trots, present participle trotting, simple past and past participle trotted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move along briskly; specifically, to move at a pace between a walk and a run.
examples: I didn't want to miss my bus, so I trotted the last few hundred yards to the stop.
The dog trotted along obediently by his master's side.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a horse) To move at a gait between a walk and a canter.
(transitive) To cause to move, as a horse or other animal, in the pace called a trot; to cause to run without galloping or cantering.
(UK, slang, archaic, transitive) To bid against (a person) at an auction, so as to raise the price of the goods.
examples: A particular friend of mine complained that I had "trotted" him at a sale, but he did not see what was happening on the part of the other bidder.

description: Short for foxtrot, whose rhythms influenced the genre.

entries.meaning: A genre of Korean pop music employing repetitive rhythm and vocal inflections.
